newsitem.title: USA: U.S. trade gap rises 7.8 percent in April.
newsitem.headline: U.S. trade gap rises 7.8 percent in April.

text.p: The U.S. trade deficit in April rose 7.8 percent to $8.4 billion as record exports were not enough to offset record imports, the Department of Commerce said on Thursday.

The department said exports, led by increased sales of telecommunications equipment, rose 0.2 percent to a record $78.36 billion in April. Imports, reflecting strong demand for clothes, toys, sporting goods and other consumer products, rose 0.9 percent to $86.72 billion, the department said.
The rise in the April trade deficit, from a revised $7.76 billion gap in March, was well below the expectations of Wall Street analysts, who were looking for a $10 billion trade gap in the month.

"Exports are showing considerable strength, which is particularly good news in the face of a strong dollar," said Lynn Reaser, chief economist at Barnett Bank Inc. "It indicates the improvement in various countries throughout the world and that U.S productivity is allowing good export performance."

The U.S. trade deficit with China jumped 33.3 percent to $3.45 billion in April, up from $2.59 billion in March, the department said. The deficit with Japan widened by 5.1 percent in April to $4.84 billion, compared with $4.61 billion in March. The department said it was the highest trade gap with Japan since an October 1996 deficit of $4.9 billion.

The trade deficit with Canada dropped by 26.3 percent in April to $970 million, the lowest monthly U.S. deficit with Canada since March 1995. The U.S. deficit with Mexico shrank by 5.2 percent in April to $1.4 billion, the department said.

The United States recorded a $486 million trade deficit with Western Europe in April after enjoying a $320 million surplus in March. In the first four months of the year, the United States has had a cumulative $1.15 billion shortfall in trade with struggling Western European economies.
The United States typically runs a surplus on its trade with other countries in services like travel and tourism that partly offsets big merchandise trade deficits.
The merchandise trade gap rose 1.6 percent in April to $15.11 billion, while the services surplus fell 5.2 percent to $6.75 billion from $7.12 billion, the department said.
